description: After days of deliberation, Nikola Petrak quietly advises the Council to take full control of all truth records, arguing that a single, centralized justice process is critical to restoring order. He urges the blocking of local access, despite objections from free zone representatives.

The Council accepts Nikola's recommendation and issues a directive: all neighborhood truth assemblies must suspend activity and immediately submit archives to the Directorate for 'safeguarding.' Archive access becomes dependent on Council approval.

In a citywide broadcast, Council leaders launch the 'Unified Civic Charter,' mandating free zone councils to register and display BCI credentials. Directorate agents attempt to enforce the transition using outdated BCI compliance lists, causing confusion.

Outraged free zone leaders expose evidence that most councils never consented to the Charter or central registry. Neighborhoods stage nonviolent protests, openly refusing BCI enforcement and demanding the right to self-organize.

Citizens across Stenograd hold 'Renunciation Days,' publicly discarding their BCI tokens and renouncing Council authority. BCI compliance drops sharply, and the legitimacy of the Council and its centralized justice effort collapses.
